lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: That which hath made them drunk hath made me bold What hath quenchd them hath given me fire. Hark! Peace! It was the owl that shriekd, the fatal bellman, Which gives the sternst goodnight. He is about it: The doors are open and the surfeited grooms Do mock their charge with snores: I have druggd their possets, That death and nature do contend about them, Whether they live or die.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Alack, I am afraid they have awaked, And tis not done. The attempt and not the deed Confounds us. Hark! I laid their daggers ready He could not miss em. Had he not resembled My father as he slept, I had donet. My husband!

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: I have done the deed. Didst thou not hear a noise

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: I heard the owl scream and the crickets cry. Did not you speak

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Hark! Who lies i the second chamber

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: A foolish thought, to say a sorry sight.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Theres one did laugh ins sleep, and one cried Murder! That they did wake each other: I stood and heard them: But they did say their prayers, and addressd them Again to sleep.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: One cried God bless us! and Amen the other As they had seen me with these hangmans hands. Listening their fear, I could not say Amen, When they did say God bless us!

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: But wherefore could not I pronounce Amen I had most need of blessing, and Amen Stuck in my throat.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: These deeds must not be thought After these ways so, it will make us mad.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Methought I heard a voice cry Sleep no more! Macbeth does murder sleep, the innocent sleep, Sleep that knits up the ravelld sleeve of care, The death of each days life, sore labours bath, Balm of hurt minds, great natures second course, Chief nourisher in lifes feast,

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Still it cried Sleep no more! to all the house: Glamis hath murderd sleep, and therefore Cawdor Shall sleep no more Macbeth shall sleep no more.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Who was it that thus cried Why, worthy thane, You do unbend your noble strength, to think So brainsickly of things. Go get some water, And wash this filthy witness from your hand. Why did you bring these daggers from the place They must lie there: go carry them and smear The sleepy grooms with blood.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Ill go no more: I am afraid to think what I have done Look ont again I dare not.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: Infirm of purpose! Give me the daggers: the sleeping and the dead Are but as pictures: tis the eye of childhood That fears a painted devil. If he do bleed, Ill gild the faces of the grooms withal For it must seem their guilt.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: Whence is that knocking How ist with me, when every noise appals me What hands are here ha! they pluck out mine eyes. Will all great Neptunes ocean wash this blood Clean from my hand No, this my hand will rather The multitudinous seas in incarnadine, Making the green one red.

lines.speaker: lady macbeth
lines.text: My hands are of your colour but I shame To wear a heart so white. I hear a knocking At the south entry: retire we to our chamber A little water clears us of this deed: How easy is it, then! Your constancy Hath left you unattended. Hark! more knocking. Get on your nightgown, lest occasion call us, And show us to be watchers. Be not lost So poorly in your thoughts.

lines.speaker: macbeth
lines.text: To know my deed, twere best not know myself. Wake Duncan with thy knocking! I would thou couldst!
